propositions.text: The story of the "Stryles Manor Case" is being recounted to refute rumors.
The narrator, Hastings, is requested by his friend Poirot and the Cavendish family to write the full story.
Hastings is on sick leave after being sent home from the front lines.
He is recovering in a rather depressing convalescent home.
Hastings encounters John Cavendish, whom he hasn't seen in years.
He barely knows John, who is fifteen years older than him.
Hastings used to visit Styles Court, his mother's country estate, as a child.
John invites Hastings to Styles Court for his vacation.
John mentions his mother would be happy to see him after so many years.
John reveals his mother has remarried.
Hastings expresses visible surprise.
He remembers John's mother as a dignified, middle-aged woman, likely over seventy now.
She was energetic, decisive, fond of charity work, and played the role of a 'busy' lady.
She was also a generous woman with considerable personal wealth.
Styles Court was purchased by Mr. Cavendish before their marriage.
He was completely under his wife's control, and the estate was left to her for life upon his death.
Most of her income also went to her.
This arrangement was unfair to his two sons.
However, their stepmother was very generous to them.
They considered her their own mother as they were young when their father remarried.
Lawrence, the younger brother, is an educated man.
He had qualified as a doctor but abandoned the profession to pursue literary ambitions.
His poetry never achieved significant recognition.
John worked as a barrister for a while but eventually adopted a more comfortable country gentleman's life.
He married two years prior and lives at Styles with his wife.
Hastings feels John would prefer more financial support from his mother to have his own home.
The old lady is autocratic and wants her arrangements followed, holding the financial power.
John expresses his distaste for his mother's new husband, Alfred.
He calls him a "vile, disgusting cad."
He states it makes their lives difficult.
Evelyn, the mother's housekeeper and companion, is also mentioned.
She is described as an "all-around person" and a "great flirt."
She is neither young nor beautiful, and people mock them.
Alfred, Evelyn's supposed distant cousin, appeared and was hired as secretary by the mother.
Alfred is a vulgar man with a large black beard and wears patent leather boots regardless of the weather.
The mother immediately took a liking to him.
She manages hundreds of social organizations.
The mother announced her engagement to Alfred three months prior.
Alfred is at least twenty years younger than her.
It was an obvious pursuit of a rich woman.
She married him due to her autocratic nature.
Hastings arrives at Styles station.
It's a small, unremarkable station surrounded by green fields.
John Cavendish meets him and leads him to the car.
John mentions they managed to get some petrol thanks to his mother's efforts.
Styles village is about two miles from the station.
Styles Court is a mile in the opposite direction.
It's a peaceful, warm day in early July.
The Essex countryside appears verdant and tranquil under the afternoon sun.
It's hard to believe a war is underway not far away.
Hastings feels transported to another world.
John expresses concern that Hastings might find Styles too quiet.
Hastings states that quiet is exactly what he needs.
John describes his own life: twice-weekly drills with volunteers, helping on the farm, and his wife doing farm work.
His wife gets up at five every morning to milk cows until lunch.
He adds that life would be idyllic if not for Alfred Inglethorp.
John mentions they might not have time to pick up Cynthia.
Hastings asks if Cynthia is John's wife.
John clarifies that Cynthia is his mother's adopted daughter.
She is the daughter of an old school friend of his mother's who married a scoundrel and became penniless.
His mother rescued her.
Cynthia has been with them for nearly two years.
She works at the Red Cross hospital in Tarminst, seven miles away.
They arrive at a tall, old-fashioned house.
A woman in a wide tweed skirt is tending flowerbeds and straightens up upon their arrival.
John introduces her as Miss Howard, the housekeeper.
Miss Howard greets Hastings warmly.
She has a strong handshake that almost hurts Hastings.
She has sun-tanned skin and bright blue eyes.
She is a pleasing woman of about forty, with a deep, resonant voice, almost like a man's.
She has a broad, sturdy build and wears sturdy boots.
Her speech is concise.
Miss Howard makes a remark about weeds growing like wildfire and the need to keep them down.
Hastings replies that he would be glad to be useful.
Miss Howard dismisses his statement, saying "Never say that. I hope you never will."
John laughs and asks Miss Howard where they will have tea, inside or out.
Miss Howard chooses outside, given the good weather.
John tells her she has done enough gardening for the day and should rest, quoting 'the labourer is worthy of his hire.'
Miss Howard agrees and leads the way to the tea spot under a large maple tree.
A man stands up from a wicker chair and approaches them.
John introduces him as his wife, Mary Cavendish.
Hastings will never forget his first impression of Mary Cavendish.
She is tall and slender, with graceful lines in the bright sunlight.
Her vivacious expression seems to be found only in her striking brown eyes.
She possesses a silent, extraordinary charm, and a wild, unrestrained passion beneath her calm, elegant demeanor.
She welcomes Hastings warmly in a soft, clear voice.
Hastings sits in a wicker chair, pleased to have accepted John's invitation.
Mary Cavendish serves him tea, and her few elegant words reinforce his initial impression of her as a captivating woman.
Hastings recounts amusing anecdotes from the convalescent home in a humorous tone, greatly amusing his hostess.
He feels quite pleased with himself.
John, while a good fellow, is not a brilliant conversationalist.
An unforgettable voice drifts from an open French window.
It's Mrs. Inglethorp, asking Alfred if he's writing to the princess after tea, or if they should wait for the princess's reply.
She mentions other ladies who might visit if the princess doesn't agree.
A muffled male voice responds, followed by Mrs. Inglethorp's reply.
The French window opens wider, and a dignified, white-haired old lady with a commanding face emerges onto the lawn.
A man, looking submissive, follows her.
Mrs. Inglethorp warmly welcomes Hastings.
She expresses her joy at seeing him again after so many years.
She introduces Alfred as her husband.
Hastings observes Alfred Inglethorp with curiosity.
He finds him rather out of place and understands John's dislike for his full beard.
Alfred has one of the longest and darkest beards Hastings has ever seen.
He wears gold-rimmed pince-nez and has an inscrutable, indifferent expression.
He seems more suited to the stage than to real life.
His voice is oily and falsely solicitous.
Alfred offers Hastings his hand, saying, "A distinct honour, Mr. Hastings."
He then turns to his wife and comments that a cushion is damp.
Mrs. Inglethorp smiles at him affectionately as he carefully adjusts a cushion.
Hastings observes the strange infatuation of an intelligent woman.
Due to Mrs. Inglethorp's presence, a strained atmosphere and hidden hostility are palpable.
Miss Howard particularly tries to conceal her emotions.
Mrs. Inglethorp, however, seems oblivious to any abnormality.
Mrs. Inglethorp's once remarkable volubility remains undiminished.
She talks incessantly about the upcoming charity bazaar she is organizing.
She occasionally inquires about dates and times from her husband.
His attentive and careful attitude never wavers.
Hastings feels an immediate and ingrained dislike for Alfred.
He believes his first impressions are usually accurate.
Mrs. Inglethorp turns to Evelyn Howard to give instructions regarding some letters.
Her husband then engages Hastings in conversation with his painstaking voice.
Alfred asks Hastings if his profession is military.
Hastings replies that before the war he was with the Lloyd's Underwriting Association.
Alfred asks if he plans to return after the war.
Hastings says perhaps, either returning there or finding a new job.
Mary Cavendish leans forward and asks what profession Hastings would choose if he considered only his preferences.
Hastings replies it would depend on the circumstances.
Mary asks if he has any secret hobbies and what attracts him, stating everyone is drawn to something amusing.
Hastings hesitates, saying she would laugh at him.
Mary laughs and says perhaps she would.
Hastings confesses he has secretly longed to be a detective.
Mary asks if he means Scotland Yard or Sherlock Holmes.
Hastings clarifies he aspires to be like Sherlock Holmes.
He was inspired by a famous detective he met in Belgium.
This detective believed that all good detective work is a matter of method.
Hastings' own system is based on this, though further developed.
The detective was a very amusing little man, a dandy, but astonishingly sharp.
Miss Howard comments that she likes good detective novels but finds them full of nonsense.
The criminal is revealed in the last chapter, astonishing everyone.
She believes real criminal acts are discovered quickly.
Hastings disagrees, stating that many criminal acts go undiscovered.
Miss Howard clarifies she means not by the police, but by the people involved, the family; they will know.
Hastings asks if she believes she could identify a murderer if involved in a crime.
Miss Howard confidently states she would know, even feeling it through her fingertips if the culprit approached her.
Hastings reminds her it could be a 'she'.
Miss Howard suggests murder is a violent crime, more often committed by men.
Mary Cavendish interjects that poisoning is different.
She mentions Dr. Boastin said that the medical profession's general ignorance of rare poisons could allow many poisoning cases to go unsuspected.
Mrs. Inglethorp exclaims how dreadful and chilling Mary's words are.
She then announces Cynthia has arrived.
A young girl in an patriotic nurse's uniform runs across the lawn.
Mrs. Inglethorp introduces Hastings to Miss Cynthia Mudock.
Cynthia Mudock is a healthy, energetic young woman.
She removes her small nurse's cap, revealing astonishingly loose chestnut curls.
She takes a tea cup with a fair, delicate hand.
With dark eyes and lashes, she would be a beauty.
She sits on the grass next to John.
She smiles at Hastings as he offers her a plate of sandwiches.
She suggests sitting on the grass for more comfort.
Hastings complies.
Hastings asks Miss Mudock if she works in Tarminst.
She nods, calling it "a hell of a life."
Hastings playfully asks if they bully her.
Cynthia exclaims she wishes they would.
Hastings mentions his cousin is a nurse and is terrified of the "sisters."
Cynthia states it's no wonder, as that's how head nurses are.
She is grateful she is not a nurse but works in the pharmacy.
Hastings jokingly asks how many people she has poisoned.
Cynthia laughs and says "hundreds!"
Mrs. Inglethorp calls to Cynthia, asking if she can write some notes for her.
Cynthia readily agrees.
Her movements suggest she is in a subordinate position, despite Mrs. Inglethorp's general kindness.
Mrs. Inglethorp tells Hastings that John will show him his room and that dinner is at 7:30.
They no longer have a proper dinner in the evenings.
She mentions Mrs. Tarminst, the wife of an MP, agrees with her about being a model of economy.
They are a wartime family, wasting nothing, even saving scrap paper.
Hastings expresses his appreciation.
John leads Hastings to his room, which is on the left wing, overlooking the garden.
After John leaves, Hastings sees him walking with Cynthia on the lawn.
He then hears Mrs. Inglethorp urgently calling "Cynthia!"
The girl runs back towards the house, startled.
A man emerges from the shade and walks towards the house.
He is about forty, dark-skinned, clean-shaven, and looks melancholic, as if controlled by a strong emotion.
He looks up as he passes Hastings' window.
Hastings recognizes him as John's brother, Lawrence Cavendish, despite the fifteen years that have passed.
He wonders about Lawrence's unusual expression.
Hastings then focuses on his own affairs.
The evening passes pleasantly.
That night, Hastings dreams of Mary Cavendish.
The next morning is bright, and Hastings anticipates a pleasant excursion.
Hastings doesn't see Mrs. Cavendish until lunch.
She offers to accompany him for a walk, and they spend a delightful afternoon in the woods, returning around five.
Upon entering the house, John calls them to the smoking room.
Hastings immediately notices something is wrong from John's expression.
John closes the door after they enter and declares, "Well! Mary, it's a regular mix-up. Eve and Alfred have had a row, and she's off."
Hastings asks, "Eve? Off?"
John nods grimly and confirms Eve is going to her mother.
Miss Howard enters, lips tight, carrying a small suitcase, looking determined and defensive.
She declares, "In any case, I've said what I think!"
Mary Cavendish asks, "Dear Eve, is it true?"
Miss Howard nods coldly.
She explains she told Emily something she likely won't forget or forgive.
She told Emily she's an old woman and a fool for not seeing that Alfred, who is twenty years younger, is marrying her for her money.
She warned Emily about Alfred spending time with Rex's young and beautiful wife.
She called Alfred a villain who wants to murder her in her bed.
Mary asks how Emily responded.
Miss Howard makes a significant grimace.
Emily called it malicious slander, infamous lies, and accused her of falsely accusing her 'dear Alfred'.
Miss Howard decided it's best to leave her house.
John asks if she's leaving now.
Miss Howard confirms, "Now!"
They stare at her.
John checks the train timetable, his persuasion having failed.
Mary leaves, muttering that Mrs. Inglethorp should reconsider.
Once Mary leaves, Miss Howard's demeanor changes.
She eagerly approaches Hastings and asks if she can trust him as an honest man.
She puts her hand on his arm and whispers that he should look after her "poor Emily."
She claims they are all swindlers, desperate to get money from Emily.
She feels she has done her best to protect Emily and now they can take advantage of her.
Hastings assures her he will do his best but believes she is too agitated and overthinking.
She interrupts him, stating she has lived longer and advises him to keep his eyes open.
The sound of a car approaching is heard from the open window.
Miss Howard stands and looks towards the door.
She calls out a farewell, emphasizing to watch out for "that villain â€“ her husband!"
The Inglethorps do not appear.
As the car drives away, Mary Cavendish leaves the group and walks towards a tall, bearded man approaching the house.
He is Dr. Boastin.
Hastings asks who he is.
John explains Dr. Boastin is undergoing rest cure in the village for nervous exhaustion and is a talented toxicologist.
Cynthia adds that he is Mary's close friend.
John changes the subject, suggesting a walk and calling Eve Howard a "most loyal and dependable friend."
They walk through the woods towards the village.
They encounter a pretty, gypsy-like young woman who smiles at them.
Hastings comments on her beauty.
John's face darkens, and he says, "That's Mrs. Rex."
Hastings realizes she is the one Miss Howard mentioned.
Hastings has a vague premonition of dread, thinking of the old lady and Mrs. Rex's face.
He remarks on the grandeur of Styles Court.
John agrees it's a fine property that should have been his with a proper will.
He admits to being very hard-pressed for money.
He states that Lawrence spends all his money on publishing his messy poems.
He says they are all broke.
He concedes his mother has been good to them until her marriage.
Hastings feels that with Evelyn Howard's departure, something intangible has been lost, and security has vanished.
Suspicion seems to fill the air.
Dr. Boastin's face reappears, causing unease.
Hastings is filled with vague suspicion.
Hastings arrived at Styles on July 5th and will now recount events of July 16th and 17th.
These events were later clarified through lengthy interrogations.
A few days after Evelyn Howard left, Hastings received a letter from her.
She is working as a nurse in a large hospital in Middleham, fifteen or sixteen miles away.
She asked Hastings to inform her if Mrs. Inglethorp wished to reconcile.
The only drawback to Hastings' peaceful days is Mrs. Cavendish's peculiar and incomprehensible favoritism towards Dr. Boastin.
He cannot imagine what attracts her to him.
She constantly invites him to the house and goes on long trips with him.
July 16th is a Monday, a chaotic day.
A famous bazaar opened the previous Saturday.
An entertainment evening for the same charity is scheduled for that night.
Mrs. Inglethorp will recite a war poem.
Everyone is busy preparing the village hall for the evening.
Lunch is late, and the afternoon is spent resting in the garden.
Hastings notices John's agitated demeanor.
After tea, Mrs. Inglethorp goes to rest, as she has a performance that evening.
Hastings challenges Mary Cavendish to a singles tennis match.
Around six-thirty, Mrs. Inglethorp calls them, warning they will be late for an early dinner.
They stop abruptly to prepare.
The car is waiting at the door before dinner is finished.
The evening entertainment is successful.
Mrs. Inglethorp's recitation receives enthusiastic applause.
There are also tableaux, in which Cynthia participates.
She does not return home with them but accepts an invitation to a dinner party with her fellow performers.
The next morning, Mrs. Inglethorp has breakfast in bed, feeling somewhat fatigued.
Around 12:30, she appears refreshed and insists on taking Lawrence and Hastings to a luncheon party.
It's an invitation from Mrs. Lawreston, sister of Mrs. Tarminst, and a member of an ancient family.
Mary excuses herself, having an appointment with Dr. Boastin.
They have a pleasant lunch.
As they drive away, Lawrence suggests returning via Tarminst to visit Cynthia at her pharmacy.
Mrs. Inglethorp agrees it's a good idea but needs to write letters and will leave them to return with Cynthia by trap.
They are stopped by a hospital porter due to suspicion until Cynthia vouches for them.
Cynthia, wearing a white coat, appears calm and gentle.
She introduces them to her colleague, a rather formidable pharmacist whom she calls 'Nibs'.
Hastings exclaims at the number of bottles and asks if she knows what's in them.
Cynthia sighs, saying everyone says "So many bottles!" and anticipates Hastings' next question: "How many people have you poisoned?"
Hastings feels guilty, smiling.
Cynthia remarks they wouldn't joke if they knew how easy it was to poison someone.
She suggests they have tea and assures them they know the secrets of the cabinet.
She clarifies that the cabinet referred to is the poison cabinet.
They enjoy tea and help Cynthia wash the teacups.
A knock is heard at the door.
Cynthia and Nibs' expressions become serious.
Cynthia, in a professional tone, says, "Come in."
A slightly flustered young nurse appears with a bottle.
Nibs hands the bottle to Cynthia, saying something cryptic about not being truly present today.
Cynthia examines the bottle strictly, like a judge.
She states it should have been collected that morning.
The nurse apologizes, saying the head nurse forgot.
Cynthia suggests the head nurse should read the regulations outside.
Hastings infers the nurse wouldn't dare deliver such a message to the formidable 'sister'.
Cynthia says it can be collected tomorrow.
The nurse asks if it's possible to have it tonight.
Cynthia generously agrees to fill it if they have time.
The nurse leaves.
Cynthia takes a large bottle from a shelf and fills the returned bottle, placing it on a table outside.
Hastings laughs, asking if "discipline must be maintained?"
Cynthia agrees and invites them to the balcony overlooking the wards.
Lawrence remains inside.
Cynthia calls Lawrence out to join them.
Cynthia checks her watch and asks Nibs if everything is alright.
Nibs confirms it is.
Cynthia says they can lock up and leave.
Hastings' opinion of Lawrence changes; he finds him shy and reserved but with likable qualities.
He had previously found Lawrence's demeanor towards Cynthia unnatural, and her response shy.
That afternoon, they are both cheerful and converse animatedly, like children.
While driving through the woods, Hastings remembers needing stamps and they stop at the post office.
Hastings bumps into a small man exiting the post office.
The man exclaims, hugs him tightly, and kisses him passionately, calling him "Dear Hastings!"
Hastings recognizes him as Poirot.
Hastings introduces Poirot to Cynthia as his old friend.
Cynthia happily states they know Monsieur Poirot and is surprised he is Hastings' friend.
Poirot explains he knows Miss Cynthia and that he is here due to the kindness of Mrs. Inglethorp.
She kindly entertained him and seven other compatriots, refugees from their homeland.
He states Belgians will always remember her with gratitude.
Poirot is described as a diminutive man, barely five feet four inches, but of very dignified bearing.
His head is egg-shaped, and he habitually tilts it.
His stiff, upturned mustache is military-like.
His attire is impeccably neat; he would be more distressed by a speck of dust than a bullet wound.
He was one of the most famous members of the Belgian police force, possessing extraordinary talent as a detective and solving many difficult cases.
Poirot points out his cottage, and Hastings promises to visit soon.
He nods theatrically to Cynthia and they leave.
Cynthia calls Poirot a "charming little man" and is surprised Hastings knows him.
Hastings replies they are unknowingly entertaining a celebrity.
On the way home, Hastings recounts Poirot's achievements.
They return home joyfully.
As they enter the hall, Mrs. Inglethorp emerges from her boudoir, looking agitated.
She exclaims, "Oh, it's you."
Cynthia asks what's wrong.
Mrs. Inglethorp says, "Nothing," but then asks the maid, Dorcas, for stamps.
Dorcas hesitates and suggests Mrs. Inglethorp should go to bed.
Mrs. Inglethorp agrees she is tired but needs to write letters and asks if the fire is lit in her room.
She re-enters her room, and Cynthia watches her, wondering what happened.
Lawrence seems not to hear and walks out.
Hastings suggests a quick tennis match with Cynthia before dinner.
As Hastings goes to fetch his racket, Mrs. Cavendish comes downstairs, appearing peculiar and distracted.
Hastings casually asks if she went for a walk with Dr. Boastin.
She replies curtly "No," and asks where Mrs. Inglethorp is.
Mary grips the banister and hurries towards the boudoir, closing the door behind her.
Hastings passes the open boudoir window and overhears fragments of a conversation.
Mary Cavendish asks Mrs. Inglethorp if she can see something.
Mrs. Inglethorp replies it's nothing.
Mary insists.
Mrs. Inglethorp denies it's as Mary thinks and it doesn't concern her.
Mary says sadly that she knew Mrs. Inglethorp would defend him.
Cynthia eagerly greets Hastings, announcing they've had a big row, and she's heard all about it from Dorcas.
Hastings asks who argued.
Cynthia says Emily and 'him', wishing Emily would see through him.
Hastings asks if Dorcas was present.
Cynthia says no, just happened to be at the door. She describes it as a "complete breakdown" and wishes she knew all the details.
Hastings recalls Mrs. Rex and Evelyn Howard's warning but wisely remains silent.
Cynthia speculates excitedly that 'Aunt Emily' will kick him out and never speak to him again.
Hastings is eager to see John but cannot find him, sensing something serious happened.
He tries to dismiss the overheard words but can't shake them from his mind.
He wonders what Mary Cavendish was concerned about.
Mr. Inglethorp is sitting in the drawing-room when Hastings comes down for dinner.
His expression is as indifferent as ever, reinforcing Hastings' dislike of his unpleasant hypocrisy.
Mrs. Inglethorp is the last to arrive, still looking agitated.
There is a tense silence during dinner.
Inglethorp is calm, playing the role of a devoted husband by attending to his wife.
After dinner, Mrs. Inglethorp immediately returns to her boudoir.
She calls for her coffee, needing to send it before the post closes.
Hastings and Cynthia sit by the open drawing-room window.
Mary Cavendish brings them coffee, appearing somewhat excited.
She asks if they prefer lights or twilight.
She asks Cynthia to take Mrs. Inglethorp's coffee to her.
Alfred says he will take it.
He pours a cup and leaves the room with it.
Lawrence also leaves.
Mary Cavendish sits beside Hastings and Cynthia.
They sit in silence; it's a pleasant, quiet, and hot evening.
Mary fans herself with a palm-leaf fan, muttering about an impending thunderstorm.
The pleasant evening is shattered by the familiar, unpleasant voice from the hall.
Cynthia exclaims, "Dr. Boastin! How strange, at this hour."
Mary Cavendish appears composed, her pale cheeks unchanged.
Alfred Inglethorp brings the doctor in, who is laughing and claims he is unfit to be seen.
He is covered in mud.
Mary asks what he's doing.
Dr. Boastin explains he didn't intend to come in but Mr. Inglethorp insisted.
John joins them and suggests the doctor have some coffee and explain his predicament.
The doctor explains he fell into a pond while trying to collect a rare fern.
His clothes dried quickly, but he fears he lost face.
Mrs. Inglethorp calls for Cynthia from the corridor.
She asks for her brief-case as she plans to sleep.
Hastings and John are present when Cynthia retrieves the case.
Three witnesses confirm Mrs. Inglethorp was holding her coffee and had not yet drunk it.
Dr. Boastin's appearance ruined Hastings' evening.
He finally leaves, much to Hastings' relief.
Mr. Inglethorp offers to walk with the doctor to the village, stating he needs to see his real estate agent and will take the front door key.
A floor plan of the second story of Styles Court is provided.
The door 'b' leads to the servants' rooms, not connected to the right wing where the Inglethorps' rooms are.
She has locked herself in.
Hastings jumps out of bed and follows Lawrence down the corridor and long gallery to the right side of the house.
John Cavendish arrives, along with some servants, looking awed and excited.
Lawrence asks John what they should do.
John tries the handle of Mrs. Inglethorp's door but to no avail; it's locked from the inside.
The whole household is awakened by terrifying sounds from the room.
Dorcas suggests trying through Mr. Inglethorp's room.
John opens Inglethorp's door; the room is dark.
Lawrence enters with a candle, and they see the bed has not been slept in and there are no signs of anyone having been there.
They approach the door connecting to the adjoining room, but it is also locked.
Dorcas exclaims in distress.
Hastings suggests they must force the door.
He asks for a maid to wake Bailey to fetch Dr. Wilkins.
He asks if there isn't a door to Miss Cynthia's room.
A maid confirms there is, but it's always locked and has never been opened.
John rushes to Cynthia's room where Mary Cavendish is trying to wake her.
He returns saying the door is also locked and they must break it down.
They ram the door, but the frame is strong and they struggle to break in.

concepts.name: Styles Court
concepts.context: The country estate of Mrs. Inglethorp and the Cavendish family, the setting for the main events of the story.

concepts.name: Hastings
concepts.context: The narrator of the story, an injured soldier recuperating at Styles.

concepts.name: John Cavendish
concepts.context: Eldest son of Mrs. Cavendish, who lives at Styles Court with his wife Mary.

concepts.name: Mary Cavendish
concepts.context: Wife of John Cavendish, described as charming and enigmatic.

concepts.name: Mrs. Inglethorp
concepts.context: The wealthy matriarch of Styles Court, who has remarried to a much younger man, Alfred Inglethorp.

concepts.name: Alfred Inglethorp
concepts.context: Mrs. Inglethorp's much younger second husband, described as vulgar and unpleasant.

concepts.name: Evelyn Howard
concepts.context: Mrs. Inglethorp's companion and housekeeper, who strongly disapproves of Alfred Inglethorp.

concepts.name: Lawrence Cavendish
concepts.context: Younger son of Mrs. Cavendish, a doctor who abandoned his practice for literary pursuits.

concepts.name: Cynthia Mudock
concepts.context: Mrs. Inglethorp's adopted daughter, who works as a nurse and has a connection to the pharmacy.

concepts.name: Poirot
concepts.context: Hastings' friend and a famous detective, who makes an appearance.

concepts.name: Dr. Boastin
concepts.context: A doctor and toxicologist, a friend of Mary Cavendish, who appears in an unusual state.

concepts.name: Detective
concepts.context: Hastings expresses a secret desire to be a detective, inspired by Poirot.

concepts.name: Poison
concepts.context: Mentioned in the context of medical ignorance and the ease of committing poisoning.

concepts.name: War
concepts.context: Hastings is on sick leave from the war, and the war effort is indirectly referenced.

concepts.name: Charity bazaar
concepts.context: An event organized by Mrs. Inglethorp, highlighting her social activities.

hierarchy.structure: The document follows a chronological narrative, introducing characters and the setting, then detailing events leading up to a significant incident, with the initial chapters focusing on character introductions and the build-up of atmosphere, and later chapters delving into specific timelines and the unfolding mystery. The structure is divided into chapters indicated by headings.
